title: (Non-) Reproducibility: Or, what are we even doing? And how can we improve?
section: ‚Ä¶ at an individual group or collaborator level
text:
‚Ä¶ at an individual group or collaborator level

But instead, I‚Äôve started shifting to focusing on what can be fixed in a single group or with your collaborators.
It‚Äôs easier to focus on, we all have much more control over that level.
The next is, what part do we want to fix? There is a fuck ton of things that are wrong. So what could we focus on?

title: (Non-) Reproducibility: Or, what are we even doing? And how can we improve?
section: ‚Ä¶ within reproducibility and the connected open science
text:
‚Ä¶ within reproducibility and the connected open science

For me, that‚Äôs mainly around reproducibility and directly tied to it is open science.
So let me focus down on reproducibility and open science, and I‚Äôll talk a bit about what I‚Äôve been doing in that space. Reproducibility is something that we researchers could ideally easily do. And since it depends on access to both data and code, sharing code is also stupid easy.

title: (Non-) Reproducibility: Or, what are we even doing? And how can we improve?
section: Very low reproducibility in most of science
text:
Very low reproducibility in most of science






















DOI: 10.1093/gigascience/giad113

title: (Non-) Reproducibility: Or, what are we even doing? And how can we improve?
section: Even in institutional code and data archive, executability is low!
text:
Even in institutional code and data archive, executability is low!

Code taken from Harvard Dataverse Project data repositories
Only 25% could be executed without some ‚Äúcleaning up‚Äù
After some automatic cleaning, ~50% could execute

DOI: 10.1038/s41597-022-01143-6

Recent large study on general reproducibility of projects that shared code.
Initially only 25% of the R scripts could be executed (doesn‚Äôt mean results were reproduced though). After doing automatic and some manual code cleaning, than about half could be executed. That‚Äôs not bad.
Since scripts were taken from Dataverse.org, researchers who upload their code and projects to it probably are a bit more aware and knowledgeable about general reproducibility and coding then the average researcher, so the results are a bit biased.

title: (Non-) Reproducibility: Or, what are we even doing? And how can we improve?
section: Why are we ok with this?
text:
Why are we ok with this?
Verification is key to calling it science‚Ä¶

Why are we ok with this? What are we even doing? The key thing that separates pseudoscience and religion is the philosophical principle that whatever you claim you have to prove. Does this look like we are doing any proving? I haven‚Äôt even touch on the results from replication studies. So, can we even say that we‚Äôre doing science?

title: (Non-) Reproducibility: Or, what are we even doing? And how can we improve?
section: Two main aims
text:
Two main aims



To build up a process and workflow for effective collaboration that follows best practices and principles in openness, reproducibility, and scientific rigor.
To build a community around a shared project at Steno Aarhus in order to create a better research culture ‚Ä¶

title: (Non-) Reproducibility: Or, what are we even doing? And how can we improve?
section: Achieve by using many reproducible and open practices on sub-projects
text:
Achieve by using many reproducible and open practices on sub-projects

Fully reproducible analysis
Version control
Code-based extraction of data
Code reviews throughout
Publish protocol, preprint, and code

See: https://steno-aarhus.github.io/ukbAid/#next-steps

Walk-through the website.

title: (Non-) Reproducibility: Or, what are we even doing? And how can we improve?
section: Next challenge: Reviewing code, which was enlightening
text:
Next challenge: Reviewing code, which was enlightening
‚ÄúIt runs‚Äù, doesn‚Äôt mean it outputs what you think it does.

https://github.com/steno-aarhus/leha/pull/16
https://github.com/steno-aarhus/legliv/pull/20/files
https://github.com/steno-aarhus/legliv/pull/7/files


It was very difficult to balance between giving constructive feedback, but also enough and in a way that taught the person how to code in a better way or if the code didn‚Äôt actually do what they thought it did. There was a lot of that actually. ‚ÄúIt runs‚Äù, but it might not do what you think it does.
Highlights such how far we researchers are from being able to code effectively and in many cases correctly.

title: (Non-) Reproducibility: Or, what are we even doing? And how can we improve?
section: But also an immense amount of work and time
text:
But also an immense amount of work and time

Doing a code review is very difficult. It takes a lot of mental energy to understand what someone else is doing when they way they do it isn‚Äôt well thought out, well structured, or even semantically/syntactically correct.

text:

title: (Non-) Reproducibility: Or, what are we even doing? And how can we improve?
section: Strong top-down enforcement of practices
text:
Strong top-down enforcement of practices

Strong top-down enforcement of practices. PhD student doing thesis? Sorry, you can‚Äôt defend until all the code is published and (ideally) independently reproduced (or at least reviewed by several others).
Can‚Äôt expect PhD students to do it, or postdocs, or whatever. If you control or have influence on how the group does things, this responsibility is completely on you.

title: (Non-) Reproducibility: Or, what are we even doing? And how can we improve?
section: Make someone, with power, responsible for the practices
text:
Make someone, with power, responsible for the practices
Both overseeing but also doing the work as needed

Assigning someone as the responsible person for ensuring reproducibility and (someone else?) uploading code to an archive/GitHub.

title: (Non-) Reproducibility: Or, what are we even doing? And how can we improve?
section: Make group-specific package to handle common tasks
text:
Make group-specific package to handle common tasks
And assign and support someone to build and maintain it

Snakemake/prefect/nextflow (for Python)


Tools that encourage/enable reproducibility and open science

title: (Non-) Reproducibility: Or, what are we even doing? And how can we improve?
section: My current work and collaborations
text:
My current work and collaborations

Seedcase Project: Building FAIR, organized, and modern infrastructures for research data
DP-Next: ‚Äú‚Ä¶developing a sustainably effective strategy for prevention of Type 2 Diabetes‚Äù. My focus on ‚Äúdoing better research in less time and fewer resources‚Äù
ON-LiMiT: ‚ÄúAn intervention study for remission of type 2 diabetes with diet and exercise‚Äù. My focus is on building a fantastic database for them.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: Reinventing discovery
text:
Reinventing discovery
By using online open collaboration, they solved a complex unsolved problem.
A shift in research practice (=a shift in culture), solved what was thought unsolvable - in record time!

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: What worked well in this project
text:
What worked well in this project
They were, with open online tools, able to:

amplify collective intelligence
have a dynamic division of labour
modularize the collaboration
conversational critical mass
restructuring expert attention


Collective intelligence: knowledge has now been decentralized. We are many great minds in specific domains.
Division of labour: who does what? clear division is import. Have the right person do the right job.
Modularizing: 2 thing, 1) small concrete tasks (for the right person), 2) modularizing is also an effective way of building something big - think of LEGO
Critical mass: needs to be enough to keep the discussion going
Restructuring attention: complex projects have many places to look. There needs to be a system for this.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: The problems we solve are getting bigger and bigger, and more and more complex
text:
The problems we solve are getting bigger and bigger, and more and more complex
Getting a good life with diabetes and preventing diabetes are complex problems

More and more people are needed to solve the problem. Bigger and bigger organizations are needed.


To solve the complex problems we need to change/update our research culture

The methods we have previously used may not be effective to solve the big societal problems we face today.
Changing the way we work, our research culture, may move us faster in the right direction.
Note: SDCA is also getting bigger.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: We can do science because we learned it from others
text:
We can do science because we learned it from others
More researchers doing something = more opportunities to learn

Because our society has a research ‚Äúsub‚Äù-culture, we‚Äôre able to learn from other researchers on how to do research. Starting from undergraduate studies, through to PhD graduate work, into postdoc positions, and continuing throughout our careers as researchers, we learn from others in our field how to do and not to do things, what expectations are placed on our work, and how to behave and communicate our work.
Importantly, it isn‚Äôt just that there are others doing research and spread the culture for it, a big factor is also that with more people doing research in addition to sharing it, and it is consistent enough over many years, that is when a solid cultural foundation can form.
So research fields with fewer researchers, or who don‚Äôt share enough, or if the field is new, there might not yet be a strong strong culture on how to do research more effectively compared to larger, older fields. Because when there are more people doing research, you have more opportunities to learn and grow.
Just as an example, if you want to do register based research, one of the best places to learn to how to do that effectively is in the Nordic countries. Because there is the data for it, people can do the work, get the experience, and share it with trainees or newcomers. And then it starts becomes a feedback loop, as more people learn, more do, which gives more chance to learn and improve.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: Researchers tend to move around a lot
text:
Researchers tend to move around a lot

PhD students graduate
Postdocs to other institutions
TAP/staff to other labs or contracts end


Remember that I said culture is learning over time in an established group. In research, and to some degree in industry, people tend to move around a lot. Postdocs move to other institutions, PhD students graduate, TAP/staff move to other labs or their contracts end. This can make it difficult to maintain a consistent culture without some form of structure to help support it.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: Moving benefit: personally gain experience, bring new knowledge and ideas
text:
Moving benefit: personally gain experience, bring new knowledge and ideas
Some knowledge is gained‚Ä¶

There‚Äôs a lot of benefits to moving around. You as an individual researcher can gain a lot of knowledge, experience, and skills. You can also bring new knowledge and ideas to any of the places you move to, on top of building your network and opportunities for collaborations.
So we as an aggregate group can overall gain knowledge when movement happens.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: Moving cost: group dynamic changes, culture has to be (re)learned
text:
Moving cost: group dynamic changes, culture has to be (re)learned
Knowledge is also lost‚Ä¶

But there definitely is a cost to moving around. Group dynamics change, culture needs to adapt, which can interrupt the flow of knowledge and learning. Knowledge one group member gains, that they don‚Äôt share because of lack of structure to encourage sharing, goes with them and doesn‚Äôt stay with the group. New members have to learn the culture, especially for basic things like admin, where to find resources, and who to ask for help.
Without some formal structure to help retain the knowledge, we lose out on this source of knowledge to contribute to the group.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: ü§î How exactly do you communicate and share within Steno/your group?
text:
ü§î How exactly do you communicate and share within Steno/your group?
Take 30 sec and think about this‚Ä¶

With these things in mind, I want you all to think for a minute to help get you into the frame of mind for the rest of this presentation. Think about how exactly you communicate and share things within Steno and your group.
How do you share knowledge when someone asks a question or you learn something about how to do your research more effectively? Via email? Write it in a Word doc somewhere in a shared drive? How easy is it to share or save knowledge you‚Äôve gained or been asked about?
I‚Äôm going to let you think about it for a bit, and wait before moving on.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: ü§î Is your way of communicating and sharing easy for newcomers?
text:
ü§î Is your way of communicating and sharing easy for newcomers?
Take 30 sec and think about this

Doing the same thing, but a bit in the reverse, imagine you are a newcomer to the group or Steno. How easy is it to find that information that you normally share or communicate? How easy is it to know who to ask? Might you be frustrated with finding this internal knowledge?
Like with before, I‚Äôm going to let you think about it for a bit.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: A formal approach to sharing, creating, and managing knowledge
text:
A formal approach to sharing, creating, and managing knowledge
Specifically within an organization or group.

Knowledge management is a set of formal and structured methods and processes to sharing, creating, and managing data, specifically within an organizational or group setting. While we humans will naturally build an implicit and unstructured culture to allow social learning, knowledge management as a concept is a formal, described, and explicit approach than what we intuitively and instinctively will do.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: That is done in an open, accessible, transparent way
text:
That is done in an open, accessible, transparent way
Usually publicly online

A lot of knowledge management processes and methods were created in the context of an industry or corporate setting, where being open doesn‚Äôt often provide a competitive market advantage. But we‚Äôre in science, where part of the philosophy is some level of transparency and openness in our work, so that findings and claims can be critiqued and verified.
In this case, using an open knowledge management approach provides more opportunity for us to become better researchers and for our research findings can be more rigorous and higher quality.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: That stores knowledge from ‚Äúwhere‚Äôs the printer‚Äù to ‚Äúhow to run this assay‚Äù
text:
That stores knowledge from ‚Äúwhere‚Äôs the printer‚Äù to ‚Äúhow to run this assay‚Äù
Any knowledge generated or needed could be recorded

And this isn‚Äôt just for knowledge on how to do your research, it also includes basic things, like ‚Äúwho to ask for this specific help‚Äù, ‚Äúhow do I run this specific assay with the machine we have‚Äù, ‚Äúwhere‚Äôs the printer‚Äù, and ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs a good configuration for my computer to do data analysis effectively‚Äù.
Any type of knowledge that is generated could be stored in some way and re-used. You can never know when some bit of knowledge will be useful to someone else.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: That includes multidisciplinary methods
text:
That includes multidisciplinary methods

Cultural: Values of sharing, documenting, openness
Organizational: Mentor-mentee, incentive structures, prioritized
Technological: Wikis, document sharing, IT infrastructure


Knowledge management encompasses many multidisciplinary methods and angles to achieve it‚Äôs goal.
It includes cultural methods, like having values of sharing, which we researchers often already generally have because of the way we do science. It includes having a culture of recording things down, of being open with our work and how to do things.
It also includes organizational methods, like having buddy-type systems, having incentive or prioritization structures that encourage more recording, storing, and sharing knowledge.
It includes, increasingly, technological methods, like using wikis, posts on websites, document sharing tools, and general IT infrastructure to help store and retrieve knowledge.
In general, we researchers and research organizations tend to be quite good at one-to-one, direct sharing of knowledge, such as through group meetings, supervisor-student and peer-to-peer relationships, as well as general sharing through publications and conferences.
But we‚Äôre not as good at sharing knowledge within organizations and groups in a more formal, written, and structured way, as this often requires a greater need for organizational and technological support to be effective.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: Internal knowledge easily lost without a formal knowledge management system
text:
Internal knowledge easily lost without a formal knowledge management system
This applies to both research and industry

Because researchers move around quite a bit, a lot of internal knowledge can get lost when there isn‚Äôt a formal knowledge system in place. By using a knowledge management system, we can keep more of that knowledge gained from the movement of researchers. More knowledge retained means there are more chances for innovative ideas to be created and further developed, faster than would otherwise be the case. Like, it is easier to collaborate when we can make use of shared resources and knowledge.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: Open research is still new‚Äîless researchers are doing it
text:
Open research is still new‚Äîless researchers are doing it
Less people = less chances to learn and use

More people sharing openly = faster to learn and improve

Likewise, when there are less researchers doing something, there is less knowledge on that topic and it makes it harder to do. Science is incredibly hard to do well, and doing open science can make it harder because it is still relatively new and few researchers actually practice it.
So by sharing more variety of knowledge than the traditional publication output, sharing more widely internally in formal systems, we can learn and improve faster than we would otherwise.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: Like any investment, it takes time but pays off in the long run
text:
Like any investment, it takes time but pays off in the long run

And like anything, it is an investment that takes some to do and setup, but pays off very well in the future. For individual researchers at any given point in time, the pay off isn‚Äôt as tangible or strong, but as an organization, or as a group, the return on investment can be quite substantial and seen much faster than at the individual level.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: One example: Steno Common Docs
text:
One example: Steno Common Docs

Resources and support for conducting research at SDCA.
‚Äî https://steno-aarhus.github.io/research/


An example of one such system that we are doing in Steno is the Common Docs, where we‚Äôve been increasingly moving documentation and other resources to a central location to make it easier to find and share knowledge.

title: Building a culture that uses open knowledge management for effective collaboration and open research
section: Activity: Think ü§î pair üí¨ share üì¢
text:
Activity: Think ü§î pair üí¨ share üì¢

How do you look for knowledge/info in your group/Steno to do your work? Is it easy to find? Do you have to verbally ask someone or send an email? Does it take a lot of time and energy?


How do you go about sharing knowledge? Is it easy to do? Is it easy to find later? Is it easy for others to find and use?


2 min: Think about these questions and, if you want, write down thoughts
8 min: Discuss the questions with your neighbor
10 min: Group-wide discussion



Note: Emphasize the ‚Äúhow do you do these things‚Äù, rather than how does Steno or the group. I think a big part of this presentation is getting them to think and discuss the topic.

Time for an activity! We‚Äôll do a think-pair-share, where we‚Äôll think about and discuss these questions. First, you‚Äôll have a couple of minutes to read these questions, then some time to share and discuss with your neighbour, and lastly, we‚Äôll discuss all as a group.

An introductory course to a collaborative workflow with Git and GitHub

title: The forgotten child in research: Data engineering and infrastructure
section: Spreading awareness‚Ä¶
text:
Spreading awareness‚Ä¶


‚Ä¶ on the vital importance of the foundation of our data-driven world

What is that foundation? The data itself and the engineering of and around it.


‚Ä¶ that innovation and commercialization can come from anywhere

Not to limit thinking to only traditional areas like results from research.



No need to limit thinking to things that seem directly related to health, clinic, and healthcare systems.

title: The forgotten child in research: Data engineering and infrastructure
section: Personal past experiences: Data management tasks often given to unskilled MSc/PhD students
text: Personal past experiences: Data management tasks often given to unskilled MSc/PhD students

title: The forgotten child in research: Data engineering and infrastructure
section: In research organizations: Focused on beginning and end of lifecycle (collecting data and publishing), not the middle
text:
In research organizations: Focused on beginning and end of lifecycle (collecting data and publishing), not the middle


Organizations like Steno Diabetes Center Aarhus and Aarhus University, or our external partner DD2

title: The forgotten child in research: Data engineering and infrastructure
section: In small- to medium-sized companies: Don‚Äôt have maturity and/or funds to have internal data engineering team
text: In small- to medium-sized companies: Don‚Äôt have maturity and/or funds to have internal data engineering team

title: The forgotten child in research: Data engineering and infrastructure
section: NovoNordiskFonden: Increase impact of funding by expanding use of data from funded projects
text: NovoNordiskFonden: Increase impact of funding by expanding use of data from funded projects

title: The forgotten child in research: Data engineering and infrastructure
section: Examples often distill down to wasted time and money
text:
Examples often distill down to wasted time and money



Retractions because of data processing error (e.g.¬†with Excel)
Wasted time looking for data or resolving issues with data



Time spent learning niche skill to understand or structure data
Unusable data because of lack of documentation (e.g.¬†units of measure)

title: The forgotten child in research: Data engineering and infrastructure
section: ‚Ä¶ they are often custom-built
text:
‚Ä¶ they are often custom-built


For instance, UK Biobank.

title: The forgotten child in research: Data engineering and infrastructure
section: ‚Ä¶ they are often designed for industry, expensive, or ‚Äúover-engineered‚Äù
text:
‚Ä¶ they are often designed for industry, expensive, or ‚Äúover-engineered‚Äù



Scale: Many petabytes of data, not typical in research
Price: Cost per unit of storage per year is too much for most research budgets
Privacy: Health data comes with special legal and security concerns
Features: Things industry needs, but research doesn‚Äôt

title: The forgotten child in research: Data engineering and infrastructure
section: ‚Ä¶ they are often heavy on the tech jargon
text:
‚Ä¶ they are often heavy on the tech jargon


Not something the typical or even most researchers would be familiar with, would need a specialized personnel to even understand what to use and how.
So learning these things takes time out of your research work that could be spent on running experiments, doing analyses, interpreting results, and publishing reports.



Tech jargon: ‚Äúobservability‚Äù, ‚Äúdata governance‚Äù, ‚ÄúHadoop‚Äù, ‚Äúdata model‚Äù, ‚Äúdata normalization‚Äù, ‚Äúnode‚Äù, ‚Äúgraph‚Äù

title: The forgotten child in research: Data engineering and infrastructure
section: Seedcase: Improving discoverability, structure, and management of research data
text:
Seedcase: Improving discoverability, structure, and management of research data



Seedcase is to data infrastructures like IKEA is to furniture

Website: seedcase-project.org

title: The forgotten child in research: Data engineering and infrastructure
section: Designed for typical use cases of doing research
text:
Designed for typical use cases of doing research

From Seedcase Project Design Docs

Won‚Äôt help with the legal issues around your data (e.g.¬†GDPR)

title: The forgotten child in research: Data engineering and infrastructure
section: Central philosophies and value
text:
Central philosophies and value

Follow FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable), open, and transparent principles
Openly licensed and re-usable
Use state-of-the-art principles and tools
Friendly to beginners and non-tech people

title: Presentations
text: The slides below were created using Quarto (as is this website). I originally built this website using the distill R package, with the slides created using R Markdown via the xaringan package. I have been in the (very slow) process of converting everything over to Quarto. The benefit of Quarto is that I can create a Markdown version of the slides, and Quarto will generate them into HTML slides and list them below automatically. But that also means that some of my older slides I have to manually link (see the section below). That‚Äôs why there are two sections listing my presentations.

title: Presentations
section: Previous presentations
text:
Previous presentations
These slides were created using R Markdown, and haven‚Äôt been converted to Quarto yet.

October 25, 2022: Open science and FAIR principles: Under-valued and under-appreciated talk for the PhD seminar Data management in research at Steno Diabetes Center Aarhus, Denmark
August 17, 2022: Approaches to open, scalable, and reproducible data management and analysis: Training and software talk to the Department of Biology and Biological Engineering, Chalmers University of Technology, Sweden
August 15, 2022: Implementing an open and scalable infrastructure for the DD2 data talk for the quarterly meeting of the DD2
August 11, 2022: How (and why) to become more reproducible and open in your research talk for Dr. Oleguer Plana-Ripoll‚Äôs research group
April 26, 2022: A framework for an open and scalable infrastructure for health data exemplified by the DD2 initiative talk for the Steno Epidemiology and Biostatistics Network meeting
April 25, 2022: Workshop on reproducibility and open science for the National Center for Register-based Research‚Äôs (NCRR) Retreat Day
January 13, 2022: A framework for an open and scalable infrastructure for health data exemplified by the DD2 initiative talk for Steno Thursdays
November 18, 2021: Shifting Science and Research Culture Towards Openness and Reproducibility Through Education and Training talk for the Life Science Trainers
July 06, 2021: NetCoupler: Inferring causal pathways between high-dimensional metabolomics data and external factors talk for the useR! 2021 conference
May 21, 2021: NetCoupler: Inferring causal pathways between high-dimensional metabolic data and external factors talk for Danish Epidemiological Society Annual Meeting
February 08, 2021: Reproducibility and code sharing in science: Why it‚Äôs important and how to do it talk for the Diabetes Epidemiology group at Steno Diabetes Center Aarhus
January 08, 2021: Expert Corner for the Basic Human Nutrition course talk for a University of Toronto Basic Human Nutrition Course
December 16, 2020: NetCoupler: Inferring causal pathways between high-dimensional metabolic data and external factors talk for IARC Nutritional Methodology and Biostatistics Group
November 26, 2020: Tools and workflows for improving the process for scientific research to meet modern demands talk for Steno Thursdays in Aarhus
February 06, 2020: MELD Project: Metabolic consequences of Early Life adversity and risk for type 2 Diabetes talk for Steno Thursdays in Aarhus
February 04, 2020: MELD Project: The Metabolic consequences of adverse Early Life conditions and subsequent risk for adult type 2 Diabetes talk for Danish Diabetes Academy Start-up Meeting for Funded Projects
September 12, 2019: A data-driven approach at characterizing heterogeneity in neuropathy assessments talk for Work-In-Progress meeting at Public Health in Aarhus University
August 15, 2019: Analyzing high dimensional metabolic data in epidemiological studies talk for weekly Section for Epidemiology meeting at Public Health in Aarhus University

title: Working towards research that is more reproducible and open
section: Spread awareness of tools and resources for doing reproducible research (plus examples)
text:
Spread awareness of tools and resources for doing reproducible research (plus examples)



Reproducible documents: Quarto
Track file changes: Git
Share code: GitHub
Run analysis/programming: R



Helper R üì¶:

{targets}
{here}

Example projects:

UK Biobank
Scoping Review





Mainly to have discussions around these topics
As well as to spread awareness of ways to do reproducible research

title: Working towards research that is more reproducible and open
section: Question: If you had to explain reproducibility vs replicability to everyone, right now, could you?
text: Question: If you had to explain reproducibility vs replicability to everyone, right now, could you?

title: Working towards research that is more reproducible and open
section: Reproducibility: Same data + analysis = same result?
text:
Reproducibility: Same data + analysis = same result?


Like baking: Data = ingredients, analysis = recipe
HOW EXACTLY a result was determined in a study
Independent reproduction = success


Keyword here is independent, meaning another research group or third-party tests the reproducibility of a study‚Äôs findings.

title: Working towards research that is more reproducible and open
section: We don‚Äôt share as much as we should
text:
We don‚Äôt share as much as we should












Estimating the reproducibility of scientific studies is currently very difficult because of:

Nearly non-existent publishing of code/data
General lack of awareness of and training in it




Few studies on extent of code and data availability, and whether study could be reproduced. Figure shows results of some ‚Äúmeta‚Äù studies: 1) 10.1177/2515245920918872, 2) 10.1007/s11306-017-1299-3, 3) 10.1371/journal.pone.0251194.

title: Working towards research that is more reproducible and open
section: Why are reproducible and open practices important right now? ü§∑ü§î
text:
Why are reproducible and open practices important right now? ü§∑ü§î

They are part of multiple large trends like team science, computing, meta-research, higher quality/rigor

title: Working towards research that is more reproducible and open
section: Both reproducibility and open science are on a spectrum
text:
Both reproducibility and open science are on a spectrum







Any improvement is better than no improvement
Inspectability just as important as actual reproducibility

title: Working towards research that is more reproducible and open
section: üîë Independently get the same result with same data and analysis
text:
üîë Independently get the same result with same data and analysis

Can someone else bake the same food without either of the ingredients or the recipe?


If you were to give me your code and I had access to your data, would I know how you got any given result presented in your paper?

title: Working towards research that is more reproducible and open
section: Simple, tangible steps to being more reproducible (in R)
text:
Simple, tangible steps to being more reproducible (in R)



Use RStudio R Projects (.Rproj files) and the {here} package
Use standardized project folder/file templates (e.g. {prodigenr} package)
Using Quarto (or R Markdown)



Use Git on your R Project
Use GitHub to share your code
Use {targets} package

title: Working towards research that is more reproducible and open
section: Think üí≠ then share üó£Ô∏è activity
text:
Think üí≠ then share üó£Ô∏è activity

1 minute to think, after we‚Äôll share ü§©


How do you work when doing data analysis? How do you try to be more open and reproducible?
What are some benefits to being more open and reproducible?
What are some challenges or barriers?

Seedcase: Software to improve transparency and openness of managing data

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Open Science is a massive concept with a massive ecosystem
text:
Open Science is a massive concept with a massive ecosystem

All the different ‚Äúopen‚Äù components of Open Science. Source: Foster Open Science
Key thing I want to focus on here‚Ä¶ is that it is massive and can be very overwhelming.

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Open science is a spectrum, something is better than nothing
text: Open science is a spectrum, something is better than nothing

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Reality: We don‚Äôt share as much as we should
text:
Reality: We don‚Äôt share as much as we should












Estimating the reproducibility of scientific studies is currently very difficult because of:

Nearly non-existent publishing of code/data
General lack of awareness of and training in it




Few studies on extent of code and data availability, and whether study could be reproduced. Figure shows results of some ‚Äúmeta‚Äù studies: 1) 10.1177/2515245920918872, 2) 10.1007/s11306-017-1299-3, 3) 10.1371/journal.pone.0251194.

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Think üí≠, then share üí¨
text:
Think üí≠, then share üí¨

~4 min: How exactly do you work? Consider these questions:

Where do you save your files? How do you name them?
What apps do you use for work tasks?
How do you collaborate and coordinate with others? Email? Shared folders?



For ~2 min, to yourself, think about the questions.
For ~2 min, share your thoughts with the person next to you.

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Think üí≠, then share üí¨
text:
Think üí≠, then share üí¨

~5 min: How might the way you work hinder or help you with open science?


For ~1 min, to yourself, think about the question.
For ~2 min, share with the person next to you.
For ~2 min, we‚Äôll discuss as a group.

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Multiple benefits, from personal to philosophical
text:
Multiple benefits, from personal to philosophical

It‚Äôs a core principle of the scientific method: Verification



Learning more from others: For PhD students to senior researchers




More exposure and visibility: More output to show and be seen




So few are doing open science, this is a great niche!




Easier and quicker collaboration (aside from the learning part)




Finding better opportunities outside of academia


And the last one is that one reason you don‚Äôt see a lot of researchers sharing their code or being more reproducible is.. they end up getting picked up by industry and paid really well or decide to leave academia because of the barriers.
Just as an example, I found a Norwegian group who had a really inefficient workflow and decided to re-build their workflow to make use of programming, to be reproducible, to have a pipeline. I looked up the lead author as well as several other of the co-authors and guess what‚Ä¶ many of them now work in really great companies as data scientists or software engineers, probably making a lot of money and having potentially a less stressful life.

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Strong instutional barriers, such as ‚Ä¶
text:
Strong instutional barriers, such as ‚Ä¶

You will encounter a lot of resistance, a lot of barriers and hardship.

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Lack of adequate awareness, support, infrastructure, training
text:
Lack of adequate awareness, support, infrastructure, training

At the institutional level, there is no real awareness of this, no support or infrastructure. You‚Äôre basically doing this on your own. Which probably isn‚Äôt that uncommon anyway.
Your organization is moving in the right direction to resolve this issue, but actions tell more than words.

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Research culture values publications over all else
text:
Research culture values publications over all else
What would you spend your time on if we didn‚Äôt have this publication-obsession?

Research culture and incentives pretty much only care about publishing journal articles. Creating software tools or datasets to be shared, meh. Making teaching materials to help other researchers, meh. Communicating your science to the public and doing outreach, meh. Doing actual science that might take years and not lead to any ‚Äúhard papers‚Äù, meh.
Imagine if the number of publications and where you published didn‚Äôt matter for getting funding or getting a research job. What would you spend your time on? What would you do differently compared to now?

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Legal and privacy concerns about sharing data, intellectual property protection, patents
text:
Legal and privacy concerns about sharing data, intellectual property protection, patents

Legal and privacy concerns are big topics that institutions in particular focus on a lot, about ownership and so on, since research can lead to commercialization and the potential for profit. For individual researchers, we often worry about these concerns too much and sometimes stops us from doing work because we‚Äôre afraid we‚Äôre doing something wrong

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Strong personal barriers like ‚Ä¶
text: Strong personal barriers like ‚Ä¶

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Fear of ‚Ä¶
text:
Fear of ‚Ä¶

Fear of being scooped or ideas being stolen
Errors and public humiliation


And there aren‚Äôt just institutional barriers. We as researchers have fears of being scooped, of embarrassment and humiliation for your methods being gasp wrong. Which is actually just part of science.

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Overwhelmed with everything that we should do better
text:
Overwhelmed with everything that we should do better

It is also really overwhelming, having so many things to think about to make sure you‚Äôre doing solid science. No researcher in the past had to consider and think and know as much as we have to know and to do. Another reason why we need more team science, to distribute the tasks and skills.

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Need to constantly stay updated
text:
Need to constantly stay updated

You also have to constantly stay updated, and that can be tiring.

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Think üí≠, then share üí¨
text:
Think üí≠, then share üí¨

~5 min: Think of your own current working environment. What would be some practical benefits to yourself and your group to practicing open science?


For ~1 min, to yourself, think about the question
For ~2 min, share with the person next to you
For ~2 min, we‚Äôll have a group-wide sharing of some of the thoughts

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Think üí≠, then share üí¨
text:
Think üí≠, then share üí¨

~5 min: Think of your own current working environment. What would be some basic challenges or barriers to yourself and your group to practicing open science?


For ~1 min, to yourself, think about the question.
For ~2 min, share with the person next to you
For ~2 min, we‚Äôll have a group-wide sharing of some of the thoughts

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Some core principles
text:
Some core principles

Use open source tools wherever possible
Use plain text as often as possible
Upload and share publicly early and often
Upload and share publicly as many things as possible
Archive to get a DOI/version for major milestones

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Core tools and services to help be more open
text:
Core tools and services to help be more open



Task
Tool/service




Reproducible papers
Markdown tools like Quarto


Track changes to files and version them
Git (software)


Share content like text or code
GitHub (service)


Conduct analysis or do programming
R or Python


Archive a milestone, like first submission
Zenodo or OSF

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Potential social actions to use to be more open
text:
Potential social actions to use to be more open

Do code/paper reviews through through GitHub



Instead of emailing documents around, send links a GitHub repository




Require writing everything in Markdown




Run (in)formal training sessions for learning R/Python




Agree on a standard folder and file structure for projects




Require papers be uploaded to an archive before submission to a journal


Now that we‚Äôre getting more into thinking about benefits and barriers, we can get into thinking about potential actions to take to be more reproducible and open. Before getting into brainstorming activities, I want to give you some ideas for actions to help prime your thinking.

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Think üí≠, then share üí¨
text:
Think üí≠, then share üí¨

~6 minutes: What are some ways you could personally change or improve your work to start following more open scientific principles?


For ~1 min, to yourself, think about the questions
For ~2 min, share your thoughts with the person next to you
For ~3 min, we‚Äôll have a group-wide sharing of some of the thoughts

title: Open Science in Health: Practical perspectives and actions toward openness
section: Brainstorm üå©Ô∏è, then share üí¨
text:
Brainstorm üå©Ô∏è, then share üí¨

~6 minutes: What are some possible actions you and your research group could practically do relatively easily and within the short-term (<6 months) to be more open?


For ~3 min, brainstorm with the person next to you on possible actions to take
For ~3 min, we‚Äôll briefly go over and discuss some of the ideas

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: We are woefully behind in the tools we use and knowledge we have on data engineering and programming
text: We are woefully behind in the tools we use and knowledge we have on data engineering and programming

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: And this impacts our ability to do research effectively and productively
text: And this impacts our ability to do research effectively and productively

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: Why is this important?
text:
Why is this important?

Speed impacts time to results
Ability to do more complex analysis with more data
Resources (which cost money)

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: Parquet is a column-based data storage format
text:
Parquet is a column-based data storage format
Most data formats are row-based, like CSV. Newer formats tend to be column-based.


Row-based
name,sex,age
Tim,M,30
Jenny,F,25

Column-based
name,Tim,Jenny
sex,M,F
age,30,25

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: Column-based storage has many advantages
text:
Column-based storage has many advantages


Compression
name,Tim,Sam,Jenny
sex,M,F,F
age,30,30,25
‚Ä¶becomes‚Ä¶
name,Tim,Jenny,Sam
sex,M,F{2}
age,30{2},25

Loading

Computers read by lines
Per line = same data type
Only read needed columns

sex,M,F
age,30,25

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: Parquet is 50-75% smaller than other formats
text:
Parquet is 50-75% smaller than other formats

File size between CSV, Parquet, Stata, and SAS for bef register for 2017.


File type
Size (MB)




SAS (.sas7bdat)
1.45 Gb


CSV (.csv)
~90% of SAS


Stata (.dta)
745 Mb


Parquet (.parquet)
398 Mb

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: Can partition data by a value (e.g.¬†year) and load all at once
text:
Can partition data by a value (e.g.¬†year) and load all at once
bef/year=2018/part-0.parquet
bef/year=2019/part-0.parquet
bef/year=2020/part-0.parquet
bef/year=2021/part-0.parquet
bef/year=2022/part-0.parquet

Load in R with arrow package:
bef <- arrow::open_dataset("bef")

Loads all years fraction of a second (compare to ~5 min for one year without using Parquet)

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: SAS and Python can load Parquet but not Stata
text: SAS and Python can load Parquet but not Stata

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: DuckDB is a recent SQL engine designed for analytical queries
text: DuckDB is a recent SQL engine designed for analytical queries

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: SQL, or Structured Query Language, is a language for managing and querying databases
text: SQL, or Structured Query Language, is a language for managing and querying databases

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: Is impressively fast
text:
Is impressively fast

Faster than almost all other tools

Relatively complex queries (joins, group by, aggregates) on 55 Gb takes < 7.5 min 1
Generally, simpler queries take < 10 seconds for massive datasets

Easily connects with Parquet datasets

From benchmark results page.

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: Example in DST
text:
Example in DST

Load all 45 years of BEF
Drop all missing PNR
Group by year
Count sex


Takes < 6 seconds

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: Can be easily used in R
text:
Can be easily used in R
Integrates with tidyverse:
library(tidyverse)
library(arrow)
open_dataset("path/to/bef") %>%
  to_duckdb() %>%
  filter(PNR != "") %>%
  count(year, KOEN)

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: Python can use DuckDB, but not Stata or SAS
text: Python can use DuckDB, but not Stata or SAS

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: Running multiple sessions or cores at once
text: Running multiple sessions or cores at once

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: Incredibly easy to do in R with furrr
text:
Incredibly easy to do in R with furrr
library(tidyverse)
library(furrr)
plan(multisession)
# model_formula and generate_results are
# created elsewhere
future_map(
  model_formula,
  generate_results
)


furrr = future + purrr packages

title: Modern, fast, and powerful approaches to working with data on Denmark Statistics
section: Greatly reduce time to results
text:
Greatly reduce time to results

Example: Converting 1800 SAS files to Parquet takes <12 hours, compared to >7 days

text:

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: Software to simplify and automate research tasks
text:
Software to simplify and automate research tasks

Seedcase Project: Building FAIR, organized, and modern infrastructures for research data


We are a team of 4, with two research software engineers, a database administrator/developer, and myself. Working full-time, on a project that has several products.

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: Three areas of focus: UK Biobank, DP-Next, community-building/using GitHub across Steno Aarhus
text: Three areas of focus: UK Biobank, DP-Next, community-building/using GitHub across Steno Aarhus

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: Two main aims of this project
text:
Two main aims of this project



To build up a process and workflow for effective collaboration that follows best practices and principles in openness, reproducibility, and scientific rigor.
To build a community around a shared project at Steno Aarhus in order to create a better research culture ‚Ä¶

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: Achieve by using many reproducible and open practices on sub-projects
text:
Achieve by using many reproducible and open practices on sub-projects

Fully reproducible analysis
Version control
Code-based extraction of data
Code reviews throughout
Publish protocol, preprint, and code

See: https://steno-aarhus.github.io/ukbAid/#next-steps

Walk-through the website.

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: My personal aim: Automate/streamline many project organization/management tasks
text:
My personal aim: Automate/streamline many project organization/management tasks

Go back to the image and highlight areas I wanted to automate.

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: UK Biobank and RAP a great opportunity to do reproducibility
text:
UK Biobank and RAP a great opportunity to do reproducibility

RAP = Research Analysis Platform from DNAnexus
Clean, empty environment every time you start up

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: Biggest challenge: Working with RAP is a mess
text:
Biggest challenge: Working with RAP is a mess

This challenge represents a lot of the struggles I had with this project in general. E.g. RAP has/had lack of support for R projects, mostly targeted Python users (but still not well).

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: Documentation was/is near to the lowest priority they had
text:
Documentation was/is near to the lowest priority they had

‚Ä¶ UK Biobank had to write their own guides

Extremely difficult to navigate the website and find information or guides. Kinda to the point that UK Biobank themselves had to write guides for using it.

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: Extracting a subset of data was way too difficult
text:
Extracting a subset of data was way too difficult



Behaviour of some of their code changed.
Nearly impossible to test out code locally.
Would often fail without explanation when ran on their servers.






(coming from someone who is very technically inclined and knowledgeable)

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: But finally created an R package to help others out
text:
But finally created an R package to help others out
https://github.com/steno-aarhus/ukbAid

This was a huge effort, and took a lot of time and debugging and diving into the technical details of RAP to get to this point.
Go over the ‚Äúworking with RAP‚Äù section.
Briefly go over admin section.
Then go to completed projects and show Niels‚Äô project.

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: Next challenge: Reviewing code, which was enlightening
text:
Next challenge: Reviewing code, which was enlightening
‚ÄúIt runs‚Äù, doesn‚Äôt mean it outputs what you think it does.

https://github.com/steno-aarhus/leha/pull/16
https://github.com/steno-aarhus/legliv/pull/20/files
https://github.com/steno-aarhus/legliv/pull/7/files


It was very difficult to balance between giving constructive feedback, but also enough and in a way that taught the person how to code in a better way or if the code didn‚Äôt actually do what they thought it did. There was a lot of that actually. ‚ÄúIt runs‚Äù, but it might not do what you think it does.
Highlights such how far we researchers are from being able to code effectively and in many cases correctly.

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: But also an immense amount of work and time
text:
But also an immense amount of work and time

Doing a code review is very difficult. It takes a lot of mental energy to understand what someone else is doing when they way they do it isn‚Äôt well thought out, well structured, or even semantically/syntactically correct.

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: Basically done by only me
text: Basically done by only me

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: Pressure to publish and limited training = lower priority for reproducibility
text:
Pressure to publish and limited training = lower priority for reproducibility

Limited understanding or effective use of GitHub
PhD students and postdocs don‚Äôt get rewarded for getting it right, they get rewarded for publishing


So they focus on that (they don‚Äôt embrace the reason, they only intellectually understand it)

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: I had to step back because it was burning me out
text: I had to step back because it was burning me out

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: Important thing I learned: We desperately need TEAMS!
text: Important thing I learned: We desperately need TEAMS!

text:
Work package 1: Better research in less time and fewer resources
https://dp-next.github.io/wp1-ros/

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: Lessons learned from UK Biobank experience
text:
Lessons learned from UK Biobank experience

Strong ‚Äútop-down‚Äù approach
Establish tech leads group
Emphasize more training
Have a clearer roadmap

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: Big challenges: Majority of researchers don‚Äôt know how to use GitHub
text:
Big challenges: Majority of researchers don‚Äôt know how to use GitHub
So: Lots of training and education needed

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: But having a community helps to not feel alone
text: But having a community helps to not feel alone

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization
section: Lessons learned
text:
Lessons learned

We need more digitally-technical people in research!
We need this work to be recognized and incentivised
We need this work to be funded
We need team science!

title: Integrating open and reproducible practices within a research organization

text:
Implementing change‚Ä¶
Rant and don‚Äôt stop ranting!
